description: Students take a closer look at the heart: its four chambers, the valves that prevent backflow, and the electrical system that keeps it beating rhythmically. They learn about heart-healthy habits: exercise, nutrition, stress management, and sleep.
instructions:
1. Review the circulatory system from Day 2.
2. Zoom into the heart: four chambers — 2 atria (receiving rooms) and 2 ventricles (pumping rooms).
3. Right side: pumps blood to lungs. Left side: pumps blood to body.
4. VALVES: one-way doors that prevent blood from flowing backward.
5. Listen: 'lub-DUB' sound is valves closing.
6. The heart's electrical system: a built-in pacemaker.
7. Heart-healthy habits: exercise, fruits/vegetables, less sugar, sleep, managing stress.
8. Students label a detailed heart diagram.
9. Calculate: How many times does the heart beat in an hour? A day? A year?
10. Create a 'Healthy Heart' pledge in science journal.

slides.heading: The Heart
slides.subheading: Four Chambers and a Lifetime of Beating

slides.setup_instructions: Print a large, detailed heart diagram showing four chambers, valves, and major blood vessels. If a stethoscope is available, let children listen to their heartbeats and identify the 'lub-DUB' sound.

slides.text: Your heart has FOUR CHAMBERS — like a house with four rooms. The two upper chambers are called ATRIA (singular: atrium) — they RECEIVE blood coming into the heart. The two lower chambers are called VENTRICLES — they are strong, muscular rooms that PUMP blood out. The RIGHT side handles blood going to the LUNGS. The LEFT side handles blood going to the BODY.

Between each chamber are VALVES — one-way doors that snap shut to prevent blood from flowing backward. The 'lub-DUB' sound of your heartbeat is actually the sound of valves CLOSING! 'Lub' = the valves between atria and ventricles close. 'DUB' = the valves at the exits of the ventricles close. Two sounds per beat, 100,000 beats per day!

The heart has its own ELECTRICAL SYSTEM — a natural pacemaker called the SA node that sends electrical signals telling the heart WHEN to beat. You do not have to THINK about making your heart beat — it runs on autopilot, adjusting its rate based on what your body needs. During exercise, it speeds up. During sleep, it slows down. Remarkable!

You can keep your heart healthy for a LIFETIME with good habits: EXERCISE regularly (the heart is a muscle — it gets stronger with use). Eat HEART-HEALTHY foods (fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish). Limit sugar and unhealthy fats. Get enough SLEEP (your heart rests too). Manage STRESS through deep breathing, nature time, and talking about feelings.

slides.prompt:
1. Label the heart diagram: right atrium, left atrium, right ventricle, left ventricle, valves, aorta (main artery), pulmonary artery (to lungs), veins.
2. Color: blue for deoxygenated blood paths, red for oxygenated blood paths.
3. MATH CHALLENGE: If your heart beats 70 times per minute, how many beats per hour? (4,200) Per day? (100,800) Per year? (36,792,000!)
4. Create a 'Healthy Heart Pledge' — write 5 habits you will practice to keep your heart strong.
5. If available, listen to your heartbeat with a stethoscope. Can you hear 'lub-DUB'?

slides.text: Your heart is the most hardworking organ in your body — beating over 100,000 times per day, every day of your life, without ever taking a break. Understanding how it works helps you appreciate this remarkable muscle and motivates you to take care of it. The healthy habits you start NOW will keep your heart strong for decades to come.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the four chambers of the heart? Can they explain the path blood takes through the heart? Do they understand what causes the heartbeat sound? Can they describe at least 3 heart-healthy habits?

parent_notes: The detailed heart study builds on the circulatory system overview. The math calculation (heartbeats per year) makes the heart's workload tangible and impressive. The 'lub-DUB' sound explanation demystifies something children can feel in their own chests. The heart health pledge connects science to personal decision-making. Consider making heart health a family project: exercising together, cooking heart-healthy meals, establishing good sleep routines. The heart is the first organ children can feel working in their own bodies, making it an ideal entry point for anatomy studies. If your child is interested, explore more about the heart: watch videos of heart surgery, learn about heart transplants, or study how the heart develops in embryos.

title: Printmaking — Creating Repeated Patterns with Stamps
description: Students explore the art of printmaking by creating their own stamps from craft foam, erasers, or potatoes. They learn about repeated patterns, symmetry, and how printmaking has been used throughout history to reproduce images and create decorative art.
instructions:
1. Introduce PRINTMAKING: creating art by pressing an inked surface onto paper.
2. History: printmaking has been used for thousands of years (Chinese woodblocks, Gutenberg press).
3. Demonstrate making a simple stamp from craft foam glued to cardboard.
4. Show techniques: inking the stamp, pressing firmly, lifting cleanly.
5. Create repeated patterns: rows, alternating colors, borders.
6. Discuss SYMMETRY in pattern design.
7. Students design and cut their own stamps.
8. Practice printing: rows, borders, and allover patterns.
9. Create a finished print using color, repetition, and pattern.
10. Display and discuss the variety of results from the same technique.

items: Ink pads or shallow trays of tempera paint
slides.setup_instructions: Cut cardboard into small squares (2-3 inches) for stamp bases. Have craft foam ready for cutting shapes. Simple designs work best: stars, hearts, leaves, geometric shapes. Set up printing stations with ink pads or shallow trays of paint. Cover work surfaces with newspaper. Have wet cloths ready for cleanup.

slides.text: PRINTMAKING is one of the oldest art techniques in the world. The idea is simple: carve or create a design on a surface, apply ink or paint, then PRESS it onto paper to transfer the image. The magic of printmaking is REPETITION — you can print the same image over and over, creating patterns, borders, and compositions that would be impossible to draw by hand.

Today we make stamps from craft foam. Cut a simple shape from the foam and glue it onto a cardboard square (the handle). The shape should be BOLD and SIMPLE — fine details do not print well. Think geometric: circles, triangles, stars, zigzags. Or organic: leaves, flowers, animal shapes. Remember: your stamp will print a MIRROR image of what you cut!

PRINTING TECHNIQUE: Press your stamp firmly into the ink pad (or dip into paint). Position it on your paper. Press DOWN firmly and evenly. Lift STRAIGHT UP without wiggling. Ta-da! Your first print! Now repeat: rows of the same image, alternating two stamps, creating borders, or filling the entire page with a pattern.

Pattern design uses REPETITION and RHYTHM — the same principles as music! A simple pattern (stamp-space-stamp-space) creates a regular rhythm. Alternating two different stamps creates a more complex pattern. Changing COLORS adds another layer. Rotating your stamp 90 degrees between prints creates spinning patterns. Experiment and discover what patterns emerge!

slides.prompt:
1. Design and cut 1-2 stamps from craft foam on cardboard bases.
2. Practice printing on scrap paper first: find the right amount of ink/paint and the right pressure.
3. Create a FINISHED PRINT on good paper:
   - Use repetition to create a pattern or border
   - Try at least 2 different colors
   - Experiment with rotation, spacing, and alternation
4. Sign and title your print.
5. On the back, write: 'Created using the printmaking technique of stamping. My stamp design is [describe shape]. I used [describe pattern strategy].'

slides.text: Printmaking shows how a single simple shape, repeated with intention, can create complex and beautiful art. This is the same principle behind wallpaper, fabric patterns, wrapping paper, and book illustrations. You used an ancient art technique that connects you to Chinese woodblock printers, medieval European book makers, and modern graphic designers. Art is about making smart CHOICES — choosing a shape, a color, a pattern — and executing them with care.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a simple stamp? Can they print cleanly and consistently? Do they create patterns using repetition and color variation? Can they describe the printmaking process?

parent_notes: Printmaking develops both artistic skill and mathematical thinking (patterns, symmetry, repetition). The stamp-making process involves planning and fine motor skills. The printing process teaches cause and effect: ink amount, pressure, and paper choice all affect the result. Historical context (Chinese woodblock printing predates Gutenberg by centuries) connects to world history. Keep the stamps after the lesson — children can use them for cards, wrapping paper, bookmarks, and other projects. If your child enjoys printmaking, explore potato printing, leaf printing, and eventually linoleum block printing as they develop more skill.

title: Community Service — Planning a Project to Help Others
description: Students learn about community service and plan a small project to help others. They brainstorm needs in their community, choose a project, create an action plan, and prepare to carry it out. This lesson develops civic responsibility and the understanding that every person can make a positive difference.
instructions:
1. Discuss: What is community service? Why does it matter?
2. Brainstorm: What needs exist in our community? (Elderly, environment, animals, younger children.)
3. Examples: food drive, park cleanup, cards for nursing home residents, book collection.
4. Choose a project the group can realistically complete.
5. Create an ACTION PLAN: What? When? Where? Who? What do we need?
6. Assign roles and responsibilities.
7. Prepare materials: write letters, make collection boxes, create signs.
8. Discuss: How does helping others affect the helper?
9. Set a timeline for completing the project.
10. Reflect: Why does the Montessori approach value service to others?

items: Art supplies for signs, cards, or collection materials
slides.setup_instructions: This is a planning session — the actual project execution may extend beyond the lesson period. Have a list of feasible projects ready as suggestions. The project should be achievable by children this age: writing cards, collecting items, cleaning up a nearby area, or making something for others.

slides.text: In Montessori education, we believe in three levels of care: care for SELF (personal hygiene, organization), care for the ENVIRONMENT (cleaning, plant care), and care for OTHERS (service, kindness, community). Today we focus on that third level: how can WE help make our community better? This is called COMMUNITY SERVICE.

Every community has NEEDS. Elderly people may be lonely. Public spaces may need cleaning. Animal shelters need supplies. Younger children need mentoring. Food banks need donations. The FIRST step in service is NOTICING needs. Look around: what could be improved? Who might appreciate help? The ability to see others' needs is a superpower.

Good service requires a PLAN. What will we do? When will we do it? Where? Who will be involved? What materials do we need? A plan turns a nice IDEA into real ACTION. Let us brainstorm projects, choose the best one, and create a detailed plan we can actually carry out.

Here is a beautiful truth: when you help others, YOU benefit too. Service builds empathy (understanding how others feel), develops skills (planning, teamwork, communication), and creates CONNECTION (feeling part of something bigger than yourself). The Montessori motto could be: 'Help me to help others' — because in serving our community, we grow ourselves.

slides.prompt:
1. BRAINSTORM: List 5-10 ways you could help your community. Think about: elderly, environment, animals, younger children, your school/neighborhood.
2. VOTE: Choose one project the group is excited about.
3. Create an ACTION PLAN:
   - WHAT: Describe the project in one sentence.
   - WHEN: Set a date or timeline.
   - WHERE: Location of the service.
   - WHO: Assign roles (leader, materials gatherer, communicator).
   - WHAT WE NEED: List all materials and preparations.
4. Begin PREPARING: make signs, write letters, create collection boxes, or prepare materials.
5. Write a personal reflection: Why does community service matter to YOU?

slides.text: You have planned a real community service project. The planning is important, but the DOING is what matters. When you carry out this project, you will experience the joy of making a real difference in someone's life. Community service teaches us that we are not just IN a community — we are RESPONSIBLE for it. Every person, no matter how young, can contribute to making the world better.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify community needs? Can they contribute to planning a service project? Do they understand the concept of civic responsibility? Can they articulate why service matters?

parent_notes: Community service is a powerful practical life activity that develops empathy, planning skills, and civic responsibility. The key is choosing a project that children can ACTUALLY complete — overly ambitious plans lead to frustration. Simple projects (writing cards to nursing home residents, cleaning up a local park, collecting books for a shelter) are achievable and meaningful. Follow through on the plan: the experience of completing a service project is transformative. If possible, involve the whole family. Service learning research shows that children who engage in community service develop stronger social-emotional skills, greater empathy, and a sense of agency — the belief that they can make a difference.

title: Research Report Presentation — Sharing Your Findings
description: Students present their completed research reports to the class, practicing public speaking skills. They learn to speak clearly, make eye contact, use visual aids, and answer questions from the audience. The presentation transforms their written work into an oral communication experience.
instructions:
1. Discuss: Presenting research is as important as writing it.
2. Tips for good presentations: clear voice, eye contact, organized delivery.
3. Introduce visual aids: poster, diagram, or props related to the topic.
4. Practice: rehearse the presentation once privately.
5. Structure: introduce your topic, share 3 key findings, conclude with what surprised you.
6. Keep it brief: 2-3 minutes per presenter.
7. Students present to the group.
8. Audience skills: listen attentively, ask one question after each presentation.
9. Give positive feedback to each presenter.
10. Celebrate: every presenter is an expert on their topic!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a presentation area. Each presenter needs space for visual aids. Prepare the audience: practice listening attentively and thinking of questions. A simple timer helps keep presentations on track. The atmosphere should be supportive and celebratory.

slides.text: Scientists do not just WRITE reports — they PRESENT their findings to others. Today YOU become the expert, sharing what you researched and learned. Public speaking is a skill that gets better with practice, and this is a safe, supportive place to practice it.

Good presentation tips: STAND UP STRAIGHT — it shows confidence. SPEAK CLEARLY — loud enough for everyone to hear. Make EYE CONTACT with your audience (look at different people as you talk). KNOW YOUR MATERIAL — you researched this, so you are the expert! Use VISUAL AIDS to help the audience see what you are describing.

Structure your presentation simply: 1) INTRODUCE your topic and why you chose it. 2) Share your 3 MOST INTERESTING findings. 3) CONCLUDE with what surprised you most and what you would still like to learn. Keep it to 2-3 minutes — short and focused is better than long and rambling.

AUDIENCE responsibilities: Listen with full attention (no fidgeting!). Think of ONE question to ask. Give a specific COMPLIMENT after each presentation ('I liked learning that...' or 'Your visual aid really helped me understand...'). Being a good audience member is a skill too!

slides.prompt:
1. REHEARSE: Practice your presentation once to yourself or a partner.
2. Set up your VISUAL AID.
3. PRESENT to the group (2-3 minutes):
   - Introduce your topic
   - Share 3 key findings
   - Conclude with your most interesting discovery
4. ANSWER one question from the audience.
5. As an audience member: listen, ask a question, give a compliment.
6. After all presentations: write a reflection — What did you learn from someone ELSE's presentation?

slides.text: You are now RESEARCHERS and PRESENTERS. You investigated a topic, organized information, wrote a report, and shared your findings with an audience. These skills — research, writing, and public speaking — are the foundation of academic and professional success. Every scientist, journalist, teacher, and leader uses these skills every day. You have proven that you can too.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child present their findings clearly and confidently? Do they speak at an appropriate volume with eye contact? Can they answer questions about their topic? Are they respectful and attentive as audience members?

parent_notes: Public speaking is consistently ranked among the most feared activities — starting young, in a supportive environment, builds lifelong confidence. The research presentation integrates reading, writing, research, and oral communication into one comprehensive project. Celebrate every presenter regardless of polish — the courage to stand up and share is the real achievement. At home, practice presentations together: have the child present to family members, pets, or stuffed animals. Video recording (with permission) allows children to see themselves and improve. The Q&A component develops quick thinking and deeper understanding of the material.

title: Division Review — All Strategies and Real-World Applications
description: Students review all division concepts: equal sharing, repeated subtraction, the relationship to multiplication, division with remainders, and the long division algorithm. They solve a variety of problems using the strategy of their choice and apply division to real-world scenarios.
instructions:
1. Review: Division means splitting into equal groups.
2. Strategy review: manipulatives, stamp game, multiplication facts, long division.
3. Mixed practice: problems with and without remainders.
4. Real-world applications: sharing food, planning events, splitting costs.
5. Division and multiplication as INVERSE operations.
6. Multi-step problems combining multiplication and division.
7. Students choose their preferred strategy for each problem.
8. Speed challenge: solve as many division facts as possible in 3 minutes.
9. Identify personal strengths and areas for continued practice.
10. Division celebration: recognize growth and achievement.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a varied problem set: simple division facts, division with remainders, word problems requiring remainder interpretation, and multi-step problems. Have all tools available (stamps, counters, paper algorithm). Let children CHOOSE their preferred method.

slides.text: You have learned to divide in many ways: sharing manipulatives into groups, using the stamp game for bigger numbers, using multiplication facts in reverse, and now the long division algorithm on paper. Today you choose the strategy that works best for YOU. There is no single right method — the best method is the one that helps you find the correct answer.

Division and multiplication are INVERSE OPERATIONS — they undo each other. If 6 x 8 = 48, then 48 ÷ 6 = 8 AND 48 ÷ 8 = 6. Knowing your multiplication tables makes division fast! When you see 63 ÷ 7, think: 'What times 7 equals 63?' The answer: 9! Your multiplication knowledge IS your division knowledge.

Real-world division is everywhere: splitting a restaurant bill among friends, planning how many days a bag of dog food will last, figuring out how many teams you can make with 28 players, calculating how many hours until a road trip is over. Division answers the question: 'How many in each group?' or 'How many groups can I make?'

Today's challenge covers EVERYTHING: simple facts, remainders, word problems, and multi-step problems. Show your work, check your answers, and be proud of how far you have come. At the beginning of the year, division was a new concept. Now you have multiple strategies and real understanding. That is GROWTH.

slides.prompt:
DIVISION CHALLENGE:
1. Quick facts: 36÷4, 72÷8, 45÷9, 56÷7, 81÷9 (use multiplication knowledge!)
2. With remainders: 50÷7, 83÷9, 29÷4, 67÷8
3. Word problems:
   - 156 photos put into an album with 6 per page. How many pages needed?
   - $45 split equally among 7 friends. How much each? How much left?
   - 200 students in groups of 12. How many groups? How many extra students?
4. Multi-step: A farmer has 84 eggs. He sells them in cartons of 12. How many cartons can he fill? How much money does he earn if each carton sells for $3?
5. Speed round: how many division facts can you solve in 3 minutes?

slides.text: Division is no longer a mystery — it is a TOOL you can use confidently. From simple sharing to long division with remainders, from stamp game to paper algorithm, you have built a complete toolkit for dividing numbers. Combined with your multiplication knowledge, you can now handle all four operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. That is the full set of arithmetic tools!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child divide using multiple strategies? Can they handle problems with and without remainders? Can they connect division to multiplication? Can they solve multi-step real-world problems?

parent_notes: This review lesson celebrates growth and allows children to demonstrate competence across all division concepts. The choice of strategy is important: children should select the method that works best for each problem, which develops mathematical flexibility. The multi-step problems introduce combining operations, which is the next level of mathematical thinking. The speed challenge should track personal progress, not comparison with others. Division completes the four-operation arithmetic toolkit (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division), which is a significant mathematical milestone. Continue practicing with real-world situations: recipes, money, time, and measurement all involve division regularly.

title: The American Revolution — Victory at Yorktown and the Birth of a Nation
description: Students learn about the final major battle of the American Revolution at Yorktown (1781) and the Treaty of Paris (1783) that officially ended the war. They explore how the new nation organized itself, the writing of the Constitution, and what the Revolution meant for the world.
instructions:
1. Review the war's progress: Lexington, Valley Forge, Saratoga, French alliance.
2. The SIEGE OF YORKTOWN (1781): Washington and French forces trap British General Cornwallis.
3. Cornwallis surrenders — the war is effectively over.
4. The TREATY OF PARIS (1783): Britain officially recognizes American independence.
5. Challenges after the war: How do you build a new country?
6. The CONSTITUTION (1787): the framework for American government.
7. George Washington becomes the first president (1789).
8. Global impact: the Revolution inspired revolutions in France and beyond.
9. Students create a 'Birth of a Nation' timeline.
10. Reflect: What ideas from the Revolution still matter today?

items: Images of the surrender at Yorktown
slides.setup_instructions: Mark Yorktown on the map. Prepare a simplified version of the Constitution's preamble ('We the People...'). The narrative arc completes here: from first shots at Lexington to victory at Yorktown to the creation of a new nation.

slides.text: After years of fighting, the decisive moment came at YORKTOWN, Virginia, in October 1781. George Washington, with the help of French General Rochambeau and the French navy, trapped British General CORNWALLIS on a peninsula. Surrounded by land and sea, with no escape, Cornwallis had no choice but to SURRENDER. The band reportedly played 'The World Turned Upside Down' — because it had.

The TREATY OF PARIS was signed in 1783, officially ending the war. Britain recognized the United States as an independent nation. But independence was just the BEGINNING of a new challenge: How do you build a country from scratch? The former colonies needed a government, laws, a leader, and a shared identity.

In 1787, delegates met in Philadelphia to write the CONSTITUTION — the supreme law of the new nation. It begins with some of the most famous words in history: 'We the People of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union...' The Constitution established three branches of government: legislative (Congress), executive (President), and judicial (Supreme Court). This system of CHECKS AND BALANCES prevents any one branch from becoming too powerful.

In 1789, George Washington was elected the first PRESIDENT. The American Revolution sent shockwaves around the world. It proved that ordinary people could overthrow a king and govern THEMSELVES. The French Revolution (1789) was directly inspired by the American example. The ideas of liberty, equality, and self-government that the American Revolution championed continue to inspire people worldwide to this day.

slides.prompt:
1. Create a BIRTH OF A NATION timeline: Lexington (1775) → Declaration of Independence (1776) → Valley Forge (1777-78) → Saratoga (1777) → Yorktown (1781) → Treaty of Paris (1783) → Constitution (1787) → Washington becomes President (1789).
2. Read the Preamble to the Constitution together. In your own words, what does 'We the People' mean?
3. In your history journal: What are the three branches of government? Why are checks and balances important?
4. Reflection: Which idea from the American Revolution do you think is most important today? Why?
5. Draw a scene from the surrender at Yorktown.

slides.text: The American Revolution was not just a war — it was the birth of an IDEA: that people have the right to govern themselves, that all are created equal (an ideal still being realized), and that government should serve the people, not the other way around. From the first shots at Lexington to the writing of the Constitution, this story shows that determined people can change the world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the significance of Yorktown? Can they explain what the Treaty of Paris accomplished? Do they know the basics of the Constitution (three branches, checks and balances)? Can they articulate the global impact of the Revolution?

parent_notes: This lesson brings the American Revolution unit to a satisfying conclusion. The arc from rebellion to victory to nation-building is a complete story of human determination. The Constitution and its 'We the People' preamble are foundational documents that children should encounter early. The three branches of government and checks and balances are core civic knowledge. The global impact discussion shows that the Revolution was not just an American event — it changed the world. The unfinished ideals (the promise of equality not yet fully realized) can be acknowledged honestly at an age-appropriate level. Consider visiting a local government building or watching a simple video about how the three branches work to make these concepts concrete.

title: Blood — Components, Types, and the Amazing Delivery System
description: Students learn about the components of blood: red blood cells (carry oxygen), white blood cells (fight disease), platelets (help clotting), and plasma (the liquid carrier). They explore blood types and discover that donating blood saves lives.
instructions:
1. Review the circulatory system and the heart.
2. What IS blood? It is not just a red liquid — it is a complex mixture.
3. RED BLOOD CELLS: disk-shaped, carry oxygen, make blood red. Billions in your body.
4. WHITE BLOOD CELLS: the immune system's soldiers, fight infections.
5. PLATELETS: tiny fragments that form clots to stop bleeding.
6. PLASMA: the yellowish liquid that carries everything through the vessels.
7. BLOOD TYPES: A, B, AB, O — determined by markers on red blood cells.
8. Blood donation: sharing blood to save lives.
9. Students draw and label the four blood components.
10. Calculate: approximately how much blood is in your body (about 1 liter per 12 kg body weight).
materials_needed: Red, white, and yellow modeling clay or colored pencils

items: Red, white, and yellow clay or colored pencils
slides.setup_instructions: Print microscope images showing red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. If modeling clay is available, children can build models of each blood component. The 'blood in a jar' demonstration is effective: layer red-tinted water (red blood cells), a thin white layer (white blood cells/platelets), and yellow liquid (plasma) to show proportions.

slides.text: Blood looks like a simple red liquid, but under a microscope, it is a bustling CITY of different cell types, each with its own job. A single DROP of blood contains about 5 million red blood cells, 7,000 white blood cells, and 250,000 platelets — all floating in a yellowish liquid called plasma. Let us meet each member of this team.

RED BLOOD CELLS are shaped like tiny donuts (disks with a dip in the middle). Their job: carry OXYGEN from the lungs to every cell in the body, and carry CARBON DIOXIDE waste back to the lungs. They contain HEMOGLOBIN, an iron-rich protein that grabs oxygen and gives blood its red color. Your body makes about 2 MILLION new red blood cells every SECOND!

WHITE BLOOD CELLS are your body's ARMY. When germs invade — bacteria, viruses, parasites — white blood cells attack and destroy them. Some white blood cells eat germs (like tiny Pac-Men!). Others produce ANTIBODIES — proteins that mark germs for destruction. When you get a fever, it means your white blood cells are fighting hard! PLATELETS are tiny cell fragments that rush to cuts and wounds, sticking together to form CLOTS that stop bleeding.

PLASMA is the liquid part of blood — about 55% of your blood volume. It is mostly water but carries proteins, hormones, nutrients, and waste products throughout the body. There are four main BLOOD TYPES: A, B, AB, and O, determined by markers on your red blood cells. Knowing your blood type matters for BLOOD DONATION — sharing your blood can save someone's life during surgery or after an accident!

slides.prompt:
1. Draw and label the FOUR BLOOD COMPONENTS: red blood cells (disk-shaped, red), white blood cells (round, white with purple spots), platelets (small irregular fragments), plasma (yellowish liquid).
2. Create a 'Blood Job Description' chart: for each component, write its shape, color, and JOB.
3. MATH: You have about 70 mL of blood per kg of body weight. If you weigh 30 kg, how much blood do you have? (30 x 70 = 2,100 mL = about 2.1 liters!)
4. In your journal: Why are white blood cells called the body's 'army'?
5. Discussion: Why is blood donation important? Who might need donated blood?

slides.text: Blood is far more than a red liquid — it is a living tissue containing billions of cells, each performing vital work. Red blood cells deliver oxygen, white blood cells fight disease, platelets stop bleeding, and plasma carries it all. This remarkable fluid circulates through your body every minute, keeping every cell alive and healthy. Understanding blood helps you appreciate the incredible complexity of your own body.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the four components of blood? Can they describe the function of each? Do they understand blood types at a basic level? Can they calculate approximate blood volume?

parent_notes: Blood components are fascinating for children, especially when presented with microscope images or models. The 'army' metaphor for white blood cells is effective and memorable. The math activity (calculating blood volume) personalizes the information. Blood types are a fun fact that many children want to know about themselves — check vaccination records or ask your doctor. Blood donation is an age-appropriate topic that teaches altruism and community responsibility. If your child is squeamish about blood, reassure them that this is learning about how their own body works — understanding reduces fear. The hemoglobin/iron connection explains why iron-rich foods are important for health.

title: Body Systems Art — Creating an Anatomical Self-Portrait
description: Students combine their science knowledge of body systems with artistic skills to create an anatomical self-portrait. They draw a life-size outline of their body and add the circulatory system (heart, blood vessels) using red and blue markers, creating a unique intersection of science and art.
instructions:
1. Discuss: Art and science have always been connected (Leonardo da Vinci drew anatomy).
2. Show examples of anatomical art: da Vinci's Vitruvian Man, medical illustrations.
3. Each student traces their body outline on large paper (partner helps).
4. Add the HEART in the correct position (left-center chest).
5. Draw major ARTERIES in red extending from the heart.
6. Draw major VEINS in blue returning to the heart.
7. Add CAPILLARIES as fine lines reaching fingers and toes.
8. Label key parts: heart, aorta, arteries, veins, capillaries.
9. Add additional details: face, hair, clothing outline.
10. Display as a 'Science Meets Art' gallery.
materials_needed: Large paper (butcher paper or taped newspaper)

items: Large paper for body tracing (butcher paper)
slides.setup_instructions: Roll out large paper on the floor. Each child lies down while a partner traces their outline. Have circulatory system diagrams visible for reference. Red markers for arteries, blue for veins. This activity requires floor space. The life-size scale makes it dramatic and memorable.

slides.text: LEONARDO DA VINCI was both an artist AND a scientist. He drew incredibly detailed anatomical illustrations that were both beautiful and scientifically accurate. Today YOU follow in his footsteps: creating an anatomical self-portrait that shows what is INSIDE your body, using what you have learned about the circulatory system.

First, lie down on the large paper while a partner traces your body outline with pencil. Stand up and look — that is YOU in life size! Now we add what is INSIDE. Start with the HEART: it sits slightly left of center in your chest, about the size of your fist. Draw it with its four chambers.

From the heart, draw the AORTA (the main artery) in RED, arching up and then down through the body. Branch red arteries to the head, arms, and legs. Now add VEINS in BLUE, running parallel to the arteries but returning blood to the heart. Add tiny CAPILLARIES as fine lines reaching your fingertips and toes.

Label the major parts: heart, aorta, arteries, veins, capillaries. You can add more: draw the lungs near the heart (where blood gets oxygen), and the brain (which receives more blood than any other organ for its size). Finally, add personal details: your face, hair, and a clothing outline. Sign your name — this is a da Vinci-worthy creation!

slides.prompt:
Create your ANATOMICAL SELF-PORTRAIT:
1. Lie on large paper while a partner traces your outline.
2. Draw the heart in the correct position with 4 chambers.
3. Add the aorta and major ARTERIES in RED to head, arms, legs.
4. Add major VEINS in BLUE returning from body to heart.
5. Add CAPILLARIES as fine lines to fingers and toes.
6. Label: heart, aorta, arteries, veins, capillaries, lungs.
7. Add personal details: face, hair, clothing.
8. Sign and title your portrait.
9. Stand back and admire: that is the amazing system keeping you alive!

slides.text: Your anatomical self-portrait is where science and art meet beautifully. Like Leonardo da Vinci, you have used artistic skill to make scientific knowledge VISIBLE. The red and blue lines running through your life-size outline represent the 60,000 miles of blood vessels that keep every cell in your body alive. You are a work of art — literally and figuratively!
slides.mastery_check: Does the portrait show the heart in the correct position? Are arteries drawn in red and veins in blue? Are the major vessels reasonably placed? Are parts labeled? Does the portrait integrate scientific accuracy with artistic expression?

parent_notes: The anatomical self-portrait is a memorable cross-curricular activity that integrates science knowledge with artistic expression. The life-size scale makes it dramatic and personal. The da Vinci connection adds historical depth. Display these portraits prominently — they generate conversation and reinforce learning. The activity develops body awareness and spatial reasoning. Children are often surprised by how much of their body is filled with blood vessels. If your child is interested in anatomy, consider a children's anatomy book or a visit to a science museum with human body exhibits. The portraits make excellent gifts for grandparents or can be revisited later in the year when studying other body systems.
